author: wired blogs
text: date: mon, 27 sep 1999 11:57:09 -0700 from: "steven walker" (azmildman@abacusnet.net)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: y2k disaster? you can bet on iti want to comment on the article on y2k betting ("y2k disaster? you can bet on it," 27.sep.99). the way each of the wagers is worded and the longshot being the craziest, i would say that these people aren't playing with a full deck. for instance, there is always going to be more firearms sold in the following year as there were in the previous year. the way these wagers are worded someone would have to be a compulsive gambler or a mental patient to bet any real money on them.i imagine that the fact that the majority of employees for most firms will be trying to take the day off on new years day of 2000, and that can be considered a y2k gliche, i guess. or we could bet that the world really is flat, and that if we sit on bell rock in sedona, arizona that the rock will turn into a space ship and we will all be transported to the moon during a supernova of the sun that will burn the whole planet to a cinder. there is no way to stop nuts from committing mass suicides on special calendar days. millenniums, comets passing, harmonic convergences, or even a beatles song.
